title: Optimizing Web Traffic via the Media Scheduling Problem
segmentation: Thank you Daniel.

So this is joint work with John Kleinberg and Robbie Kumar from Yahoo Research and today we can talk about what we've called the media scheduling problem and if you go through a lot of different websites you'll notice that sort of front and center they have this sort of fee.
Shared item here.
So Amazon is trying to sell you their Kindle flick.
It has some photo that they think you might be interested in seeing.
YouTube has a number of featured videos which.
I hope you'll be interested in.
And if you go to Yahoo, you'll notice that there's this featured news item right in the middle that they think you might want to read about.
So.

Well, we can think about is that sort of abstractly in all of these cases, some utility is gained through this sort of featured item by using that real estate on the web page and having that featured item.

All of these sites, they're getting something, so that could be something sort of nebulous is sort of general user interest, or it could be something more concrete, like ad revenue on the linked pages, or in the case of Amazon, they actually have a product that they're trying to sell you, so it could just be direct revenue from product sales.
But at this level we think there's some utility gain per impression every time.
The user comes and sees that featured item.

The website operator is giving something in the goal, then is to use that real estate in from the feature that slot and then maximize the utility that we gain sort of over the course of a day, and then the question is how can we do that given that we have a bunch of different things we could put in that item, how should we schedule them?
And in our study were going from yahoo.com from the front page, and we're going to consider the University to be total clicks.
And of course you know in some sense at the end of the day what Yahoo cares about is revenue.
But you know, it sort of makes sense.
They're trying to increase general user interest and that sort of leads to revenue and clicks.
Of course, that's what we can observe in the server logs easily.
So what's the framework?

Well, the first thing that I should say is that we're not going to be talking about personalization, and there's certainly lots of scenarios where personalization would certainly be the way they go, and that might be better for certain things, but for better or worse, a lot of these websites, they don't have any personalization.
They're showing the same thing to everybody, and that's the framework that we're going to consider throughout this talk.

So, given that what we think about is that the website operator like Yahoo has this pool of items and all of the items are sort of knowing ahead of time, you know they have a bunch of stories that were written by either Yahoo employees or offsite or something, and there's some pool of them that they can use over the course of the day, and somehow they sort of know how good all of those items are and I'll sort of talk a little bit later about how they might know that ahead of time, but you know, they maybe have some historical data if its products.
Or they can do some bucket testing and sort of early on to get an idea of how good these things are and what they want to do in order to get the most out of this featured item slot.
